title: Projects & Case Studies
text:
These projects bring together my experience in business analytics, AI in operations, and account management.
They include both MBA coursework and real client-facing work from my Business Analyst role.



Academic · AI & Supply Chain


AI in Supply Chain Evaluation (BUSI 654)


Role: Lead Analyst & Author • Year: 2025


Evaluated four large language models—GPT-4, Claude, Gemini, and LLaMA— on ten advanced questions in operations and supply chain management. Topics included demand forecasting in volatile markets, bullwhip mitigation, supplier risk, blockchain transparency, and ethical participation of Indigenous suppliers.



Designed a structured evaluation rubric (accuracy, clarity, ethical sensitivity, business value).


Built an Excel analysis dashboard with bar and radar charts comparing LLMs to human answers.


Identified each model’s strengths, biases, and blind spots in real business decision scenarios.


Produced a full academic report with APA citations and an appendix of LLM drafts and human edits.



LLM Evaluation Supply Chain Ethics Excel Analytics




Academic · Web & Portfolio


Multi-Page MBA Portfolio Website (Quarto & GitHub Pages)


Role: Designer & Developer • Year: 2025


Designed and developed this multi-page MBA portfolio website using Quarto and GitHub Pages. The site showcases my profile, résumé, project work, leadership, and a transparent appendix of LLM-assisted drafts and revisions.



Implemented a clear navigation structure: Home, Resume, Projects, Skills, Leadership, Contact, Appendix.


Used Markdown + custom CSS to create a responsive hero section, buttons, and cards.


Integrated a downloadable PDF résumé, LinkedIn link, and email contact workflow.


Documented how LLMs were used for brainstorming and drafting, with final content fact-checked and edited by me.



Quarto GitHub Pages Web Design AI-Assisted Writing




Professional · Analytics & Reporting


QBR Analytics & Dashboard Reporting (VMware)


Role: Business Analyst • Years: 2022–2024


Supported enterprise accounts by preparing Quarterly Business Review (QBR) packs for global customers. Helped project and account managers understand revenue, usage, renewals, refunds, and operational risks.



Built and maintained Excel dashboards tracking KPIs, account health, and performance trends.


Summarized revenue and usage trends into story-driven QBR decks for leadership and clients.


Collaborated with project management and account management teams to align definitions and metrics.


Highlighted variance drivers and risks, supporting better customer and renewal conversations.



QBR Reporting Dashboards Client Communication




Professional · Finance & Operations


Billing Variance & Reconciliation Analysis (VMware)


Role: Business Analyst • Years: 2022–2024


Worked with finance, account managers, and project teams to reconcile billing and revenue data across multiple internal systems, ensuring accurate reporting for large enterprise customers.



Reconciled billing, refunds, and credits so that QBR and internal reports matched finance records.


Investigated and explained billing variances and usage differences across systems.


Produced clear written summaries for leadership and account teams highlighting trends and root causes.


Improved consistency between operational KPIs and financial numbers used in decision-making.



Reconciliation Financial Accuracy Operations

title: Shravan Kumar Kilaparthi
text:
title: Reflection- Using LI,LLMs in My MBA portfolio Website. page-layout: full
The use of large language models (LLMs) in this assignment developed over the time of this assignment in the form of straight-forward drafting assistance rather than a more deliberate cooperation. Initially, I mainly used the model to work out the structure that my portfolio would have and to come up with rough copies of different pages like the Home and Skills pages of my portfolio. The LLM particularly proved useful in bringing disjointed ideas in a coherent outline and proposing headings, phrases and transitions that I could edit.
The more pages I added the more critical and selective I became with my use of AI-generated text. I also understood that when direct copying of the drafts was made, the site would be generic and will not be representative of my real life experience as a Business Analyst who is dealing with QBRs, dashboards and operations reporting. Rather, I began using the LLM output in a starting point. On each page, I posed three questions: “Is this really true?”, “Do I really sound like this?”, and, would I be comfortable making this description before a job interviewer? It was no in the initial cases on many occasions, compelling me to revise, cut and rewrite.
Another lesson was the one of actuality and proper application. I ensured that no sensitive information of the company was exchanged with the model and that samples were of high level or anonymised. I have also made it clear through the appendix where I used the LLMs and how I edited their drafts. This openness is important to me as it demonstrates that the site is not fancying itself as being purely human work, but is not placebl-ing AI either.
All in all, the development of a design of a multi-page website with the assistance of LLM enhanced my technical and reflective abilities. Technologically, I was taught to work with various, .qmd files, navigation, and GitHub Pages hosting. Reflectively, I have acquired a better understanding of my own voice and professional narrative through editing and at times disagreeing with the model. In the future, I will consider LLMs as facilitative tools mainly when brainstorming and drafting the initial text, yet I will keep up to the office hours to adopt my own judgment in making sure that the final product is accurate, responsible, as well as in line with my identity.

Contributed to workflow improvements in customer support and after-sales operations.

title: Appendix: LLM Drafts and Revision Notes
text:
The following content includes unedited drafts generated using ChatGPT during the brainstorming stage of Assignment 3. These drafts were not used verbatim in my final website.
Instead, I critically reviewed, fact-checked, and revised each section to reflect my real experience and maintain academic integrity.



Prompt Used:
“Generate a multi-page MBA portfolio website outline for a Quarto project. Include Home, Resume, Projects, Skills, Leadership, and Contact pages.”
LLM Output (Raw):

Home/About section with biography and links

Resume page with education, professional experience, and skills

Projects page with academic and professional project summaries

Skills page with technical skills, soft skills, and tools

Leadership page with leadership philosophy and teamwork examples

Contact page with email, LinkedIn, and résumé download link

Appendix page with LLM drafts and commentary

(This output was used only to determine page structure. The actual content on my website was fully rewritten.)




Prompt Used:
“Create an About Me section for an MBA student portfolio website.”
LLM Output (Raw Excerpt):

MBA student passionate about business strategy, leadership, and technology.

Interested in digital transformation, innovation, and data-driven decision making.

Enjoys teamwork and contributes to collaborative learning environments.

Revision Notes:
This output did not match my real background and was too generic. I replaced it with an authentic narrative based on my actual experience as a Business Analyst (QBRs, dashboards, reconciliation, cross-functional coordination).




Prompt Used:
“Write a leadership philosophy section for an MBA portfolio.”
LLM Output (Raw Excerpt):

Leadership is about vision, communication, and empathy.

Good leaders motivate teams, foster collaboration, and drive performance.

Leadership requires adaptability, active listening, and continuous improvement.

Revision Notes:
I rewrote the section to reflect my real leadership experience:
- Working across project, account, and finance teams
- Structured problem-solving
- Leading with data clarity
- Multicultural group work experience
- Applying servant and situational leadership concepts from class

title: Appendix: LLM Drafts and Revision Notes
text:
B1. How LLMs Were Used
I used LLMs (ChatGPT) to:

brainstorm ideas

generate draft outlines

produce first-pass text for some sections

assist with formatting and structure

LLMs were not used to produce final content.

title: Appendix: LLM Drafts and Revision Notes
text:
B2. How I Ensured Accuracy
All final content was:

fact-checked

rewritten in my own words

aligned to my actual work experience (VMware, Urban Ladder, etc.)

revised to match MBA-level expectations

reviewed for clarity and professionalism

title: Appendix: LLM Drafts and Revision Notes
text:
B3. Ethical Use of AI
I followed academic honesty guidelines:

No copy-pasting of unedited LLM text

All LLM drafts are disclosed in this appendix

All final text is original and written by me

I corrected inaccuracies and removed generic statements

title: Appendix: LLM Drafts and Revision Notes
text:
B4. Reflection on LLM Limitations
Through this project, I learned that LLMs:

generate helpful structure, but lack contextual precision

can produce generic or inaccurate descriptions of my experience

require human judgment for accuracy, tone, and meaning

work best as brainstorming tools, not content creators

This aligns with course teachings on responsible AI use.

title: Leadership & Growth
text:
My leadership approach is shaped by collaboration, clarity, and data-informed decision-making.
I believe that effective leadership—especially in analytics and operations—comes from helping teams understand the problem clearly, aligning expectations early, and communicating insights in a way that people can act on.
This reflects elements of servant leadership (supporting others’ success), situational leadership (adapting to team needs), and evidence-based leadership (using data to guide decisions).

title: Leadership & Growth
text:
My leadership approach is shaped by collaboration, clarity, and data-informed decision-making.
I believe that effective leadership—especially in analytics and operations—comes from helping teams understand the problem clearly, aligning expectations early, and communicating insights in a way that people can act on.
This reflects elements of servant leadership (supporting others’ success), situational leadership (adapting to team needs), and evidence-based leadership (using data to guide decisions).

title: Leadership & Growth
text:
Leadership in Professional Settings

Cross-Functional Coordination as a Business Analyst (VMware)
In my Business Analyst role, leadership meant driving clarity in fast-moving environments:

Served as a bridge between project management, account management, and finance, ensuring consistent and reliable numbers across teams.

Took ownership of QBR timelines, coordinating data extraction, KPI validation, performance commentary, and slide preparation before leadership and client review calls.

Exercised analytical leadership by escalating risks early when data reflected declining usage, rising refunds, performance bottlenecks, or renewal risks, enabling teams to take timely corrective action.

Demonstrated stakeholder leadership by translating complex operational patterns into simple, decision-ready insights.

This experience taught me to lead without formal authority—by influencing through data, structure, reliability, and communication.

title: Leadership & Growth
text:
Leadership in Academic Projects

Team Leadership in the MBA Program
Working with multicultural teams at UCW helped strengthen my interpersonal and collaborative leadership:

Often stepped into the role of structured problem-solver, helping teams define the scope, outline deliverables, and sequence the work.

Took responsibility for organizing data, research, and slides so the final presentation told a cohesive and professional story.

Practiced inclusive leadership by encouraging quieter team members to contribute, summarizing discussions, and checking for shared understanding.

Used conflict-free decision-making by focusing the team on criteria, evidence, and clarity, rather than personal opinions.

These experiences reinforced the value of empathy, active listening, and cultural awareness in team settings.

title: Leadership & Growth
section: Leading with Data and Emerging Technologies
text:
Leading with Data and Emerging Technologies
I view modern leadership as the ability to combine analytics, technology, and human judgment:

Learned to use data not only for reporting but to guide decisions, identify risks, and shape conversations.

Working with LLMs in academic assignments strengthened my ability to evaluate AI outputs critically, verify facts, and differentiate between computational accuracy and real-world practicality.

Developed the habit of explaining insights in terms of trade-offs, assumptions, and limitations—an essential part of responsible analytical leadership.

This mindset supports my long-term goal: becoming a leader who uses analytics and AI ethically, transparently, and effectively.

title: Leadership & Growth
section: Growth Priorities as a Developing Leader
text:
Growth Priorities as a Developing Leader

Strengthening skills in visual storytelling—turning complex operational data into clear narratives through dashboards and executive summaries.

Gaining deeper exposure to supply chain and operational environments in Canada, building on my foundation in analytics and account support.

Continuing to develop skills in ethical AI use, especially fairness, transparency, and inclusivity in data-driven decisions.

Building confidence in strategic communication, ensuring that insights not only inform but drive meaningful action among managers and clients.

title: MBA Portfolio
text:
About Me
I am an MBA candidate at University Canada West with experience as a Business Analyst supporting account management and project management teams. In my previous role, I worked closely with global clients to build dashboards, support quarterly business reviews (QBRs), and prepare billing and reconciliation reports that gave stakeholders a clear view of performance and revenue.
I enjoy turning messy operational data into simple stories that decision-makers can act on. My work usually sits at the intersection of analytics, operations, and client communication – understanding what leaders need to see, structuring the numbers, and presenting insights clearly.
Since moving to Canada, I have been expanding my skills in AI applications, data visualization, and digital workflows so I can contribute to data-informed, technology-enabled finance and operations teams.

title: MBA Portfolio
text:
What I Do Well

Analytics & Reporting: QBR summaries, KPI dashboards, performance snapshots, and Excel-based commentary.

Partnering with PM / AM Teams: aligning reports with client expectations and supporting meeting preparation.

Billing & Reconciliation: preparing billing files, checking variances, reconciling data across systems.

Process Thinking: understanding data flows across sales, delivery, and finance teams.
